div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: RACE SUICIDE AMONG WHITES.
div.p:
The official returns of the population of France, which were published last week naturally lead to a comparison with the statistics supplied by other States, and thereby to an attempt to picture the future of the great races of the world. No one can read the facts set out in cold official language without deep apprehension as to the position of the French race, and it can be but small comfort to a patriotic Frenchman that the tendency which the French display in the most marked degree is shared by other nations. Race suicide is the dominant disease of our civilisation, and bids fair to counteract all that we can effect by an improved sanitation and our victories over the armies of the bacilli. It is in France that the danger is most manifest, for while the marriage rate continually rises, the birth rate steadily falls, and the effects of this

tendency have already become disastrously apparent. Less than fifty years ago the populations of France and Germany were almost exactly equal, while that of Great Britain was much below both. Now France has less than forty millions of people, while Germany has more than sixty, and while the population of the former country is stationary, that of the latter increases at the rate of nearly a million a year. In the "battle of the Eabies" France is utterly unable to hold her own against her secular rival, and, if the present conditions continue to prevail, she must abandon all dreams of ever waging a war which shall restore to her the lost provinces, or enable her to dominate the European system. In twenty-five years the annual birth rate has sunk from 937,057 to 806,874, and the latest figures obtainable show that this decrease is progressive, and becomes more and more marked in each succeeding year. With a death rate of 780,796, it will be seen that there is practically no margin of growth in the nation.

France is the most terrible example of this | race suicide which afflicts the civilised world, but almost everywhere else the disease is | steadily gaining ground. Oar own births still | exceed our deaths by half & million, and on | population for the first time in history, 18 I greater than that of France. Yet in the last fifteen years our birth rate has sunk from something over 30 per thousand to 27. In Germany it has fallen in the last four years from 35.7 to 34.1, and in the United States the decrease has been so marked as to lead to the conclusion that the increase in the American population is due entirely to foreign immigration. We used to be told that the population would always breed up to a limit of subsistence, yet in Victoria and South Australia, where there is assuredly no lack of space or of the means of living, the decrease in the birth-rate has been over 23 per cent. in the last ten years. The few European countries in which the birth-rate is stationary or slightly, on the increase are so backward in sanitation that the death-rate sweeps away a great proportion of the increase. On the other hand, we have to get the fact that the birth-rate in Japan has increased in the last twenty-seven years in the enormous proportion of 17 to 31 per thousand. That coun: try remains the solo example of a great increase in civilisation being accompanied by a great increase in the birth-rate, unless Indien | where the increase in the population is almost more marked, be included in the category of civilised countries. In China only the universal | practice of infanticide keeps the population approximately stationary, and though statistics for that Empire must be more or less a matter of guess work, we know enough to be sure that if the practice is ever abandoned, the yellow race will very speedily find its position intolerably too narrow..

We seem driven to the conclusion that the white race is steadily losing ground and the yellow race is steadily gaining it. The black race is at present kept down by war, famine, | and oppression, bnt where, as in the Southern States of America, these restraining causes are removed, its fecundity is a matter of serious alarm to its white rival. The causes of the decline in the white race are tolerably obvious. Over-civilisation has caused us to set before ourselves a false standard of what is necessary for subsistence, and we fear to bring children into the world, lest no place should be found for them at the banquet of mankind. The worst of it is that it is the best and highest of the white race, who are most affected by these considerations. The squalid homes of Bethnal Green and Stepney swarm with children, while the nurseries of Kensington have only one or two tenants apiece. It is in the great middle class, with its anxieties and its ambitions, that the limitation of families forces itself upon the knowledge of every observer. Neither the upper nor the lower classes feel the same pressure, the one because it is above it, the other because it is too improvident or too trustful to regard it. Unfortunately, it is the middle class which is the backbone of the nation, and its gradual extinction cannot be viewed without the most serious alarm. The only remedy is a return to a simpler attitude towards lite, and the banishment of the notion that the children must begin where the parents left off. "There's place and means," says Parolles, "for every man alive," and half the problem of race-syioide would be solved if we could come to understand that the son of the clerk might be bred as a carpenter without deroga. tion either to his father or himself. "The Globe."

div.head: Mashiah Seizure
div.p: The Coast Guard Administration seized 347 kilos of hashish at Port Tewfik on the 25th instant.

div.head: Plague.
div.p: There are now 31 cases of plague under treatment, one fresh case having appeared at Alexandria and one at Aga.

div.head: Saint Andrew's Day.
div.p: The dinner at the new dining room of the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, to celebrate Saint Andrew's day to-morrow, will commence at 7.45 p.m.

div.head: The Ceneral Elections.
div.p: The elections for the Legislative Council, the General Assembly and the provincial councils will begin tomorrow and will last until Thursday next throughout the country.

div.head: A. S. C.
div.p: There will be a football match this afternoon at the A.S.C. grounds between the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers and the Coldstream Guards, and to morrow between the A.S.C. and and the Guards. Kick-off at 3 p.m. on each day.

div.head: A Nublan Highway.
div.p: A feature of the December "Blackwood" is an article entitled 'A Nubian Highway,' by Mr. A.E. P. Weigall, describing a road as old as 2750B.o. extending from a short distance below the first cataract of the Nile into the Sudan.

div.head: French "Depute de la Nation."
div.p: The electors of the French Colony in Cairo will be convoked to a meeting at the French Consulate on Tuesday next, for the purpose of electing a second "Deputé de la Nation to replace M. Vaast who becomes first "Deputé."

div.head: The Brindlel Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port-Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G.P.O. Alexandria, at 2.10 p.m. on Sunday 1st prox.for ordinary correspondence, 2.10 p.m. for registered correspondence, at noon for money orders and insured articles and at 6 p.m. on Saturday the 30th inst. for parcels.

div.head: Irrigation Canale.
div.p: The canals in the province of Kalionbieh and Sharkieh as also those in the district of Ghamer will, in common with all the canals of the 1st Circle of Irrigation, have the level of their water reduced from the 15th December for the purposes of cleaning, and navigation on all the canals with the exception of the capal Ismailia will be completely closed for a period of thirty days from the 20th of December prox.

div.head: From Niger to the Nile.
div.p: An account of Lieutenant Boyd Alexander's great journey across this continent from Lake Chad to Port Sudan has just been published. Many and varied bodies have been the previous expe. riences of the expedition, but it triumphed over all obstacles, and achieved all that it set out to do. Two boats, made of beaten steel, twenty-six feet long, and drawing 14 feet of water to 2} tons of cargo, were taken out in sections, and pieced together at Lokoja, and during the three years the expedition lasted they had to be carried on fourteen days only80 nearly did Lieutenant Alexander prove it possible to go by boat across Africa.

div.head: Capture of a Burglar.
div.p: As our readers will doubtless remember, in April last a stationer's and tobacconist's shop in the Sharia Kasr el Nil was broken into during the night, and about LE. 300 of goods were stolen from the window. An attempt was also made to break open the safe but it resisted these efforts. The thief or thieves got clear away and the police were unable to obtain the slightest clue as to their identity until news was sent from Alexandria quite recently to the effect that a small tobacconist shop there was selling articles of. far greater value than the appearance of the shop would warrant. A police investigation followed with the result that part of the stolen goods to the value of LE. 35 were discovered on the premises, the owner of the shop, a Greek named Theodossis has been arrested and brought to Cairo for trial.

div.head: Cairo's Arohlivoture.
div.p: Mr. Walter Typedale in his newly published work "Below the Cataracts" is very severe on the modern developments of architecture in Cairo. As an artist he is naturally attracted to the old picturesque Egypt that is being improved out of existence. Modern tourist-ridden Cairo is no more like the Orient "than Peckham resembles Pekin. Hardly a house that we see here existed forty years ago, and from the look of them, they may tumble down before another forty years elapse. The builders of these erections bad beautiful models near at band to inspire them ; but that fatal "PE gypte fait partie de l'Europe' of Ismail Pasha turned their attention to Paris, and now we have a shoddy imitation of that capital, with here and there some erection run up 'en style Arabe,' or, worse still, "l'art nouveau' as understood by the Levantine architect."

div.head: THE GERMAN BUDGET.SIX MILLIONS DEFICIT.
div.p: The German Budget shows a deficit of six million. Despite the economy the Government is compelled to appropriate the proposed sinking fund for Imperial debt. In order to reduce the burden upon the Federated States to five millions a new taxation is necessary to meet the heavy deficit.

div.head: RAID MACLEAN'S RANSOM. BRITISH TERMS.
div.p: The Standard says that the British terms for the release of Kaid MacLean are a ransom of twenty thousand pounds and the release of Raisuli's friends and supporters, as well as British protection against the Sultan for his past lawlessness.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H.H. the Khedive received the following persons in audience at the Abdeen Palace yesterday :
Sir Eldon Gorst, Sir Horace *Pinching, The Grand Mufti of Egypt, M. Worevodsky, introducing M. Nablas Dountch and Prince Alexandre Obolensky the new attaché to the Consulate General of Russia.
Abdel Khalil Saroit bey and Ahmed Kamel Bey, introduciendo a Zambaer Pasha, The Grand Cadi, Ahmed Zeiver Bey y Sheikh of the Azhar.
H.H. will come to the Palace tomorrow to give an audience to H.H. Prince Hassein Kamel Pasha and to Mr. Roy S. Bobbin of the Cairo School of Medicine.
The Khedive will attend the Mosque Sidna el hassein for prayer on Friday.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MARKET SCHEME.
div.p: We learn that. Messrs. Degiardé Brothers have submitted to the Alexandria Municipality their general plan and conditions attached threats for the erection of a market in Alexandria to be constructed and maintained on the most modern European lines with every sanitary advantage applicable to such buildings. We hope that this will receive early and thorough consideration by the Municipality as a scheme calculated to supply a long-felt public want of the utmost importance.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA'S HOUSING PROBLEM PROTEST AGAINST SHELVING
div.p: The following letter, signed by Cavellieri Ronci, president of the Permanent International Commission for Popular Houses, has been addressed to Chataway Bey, administrator of the Alexandria Municipality :

"The Permanent International Commission for Popular Houses expresses to you its Astonishment and its chagrin at having learned through the local newspapers the decision taken by the Municipal Commission at its meeting of the 20th inst. relative to the postponement of the question of economic houses.

"The courtesies which we received in the past lead us to hope, we do not deny it, that the Municipal Commission would have been more considerate in its dealings with us, and that it would never have decided to postpone Indefinitely so important a question without consulting the undersigned Commission and without having the statutes for which you asked mus before leaving for Europe.
"That the majority of the landlord councillors are averse to the construction of economic house we are not unaware of, and this

for reasons easy to understand, but the Commission ought, it seems to us, to question us on this subject before making its decision, for not only would we have been able to remind certain councillors of the formal promise made to us to build at their expense, as an experiment, a blook of popular houses, but we would have been able besides to approach other financiers and find the means of arriving at a solution of the burning problem of housing.

"The present crisis is a serious obstacle, it seems, to the granting of our desiderata, but this crisis does not prevent the landlords from continuing to increase the rents at a moment so critical for the population.

"The Municipal Commission always finds credit for the construction of parks, gardens, arcades, asphalting streets eto., works which are far from being an urgent necessity, and it does not find the means of doing something for the economic houses, although the lands for this object have been kindly conceded to us by the Government, and the expenses of construction are after all only a future source of revenue to the Municipal Administration.
"We beg you, Sir, to kindly officially inform us of the Municipal decision relative to this question, in order that we may take the necessary steps."

div.head: CAIRO OPERA SEASON.
div.p: The Cairo Opera season commenced on Monday night with a performance of Meyerbeer's "Les Huguenots'' which was repented on Tuesday evening. If the standard of excellence displayed is maintained, we may look for a season considerably above the average, though it is yet too early to speak decisively of the operation merits of the performers. M. Soubeyran, the tenor, and Mme Magne, the prima donna, are, however, the possessors of rich and powerful voices, and do justice to the parts of Raoul de Nangis and Valentine. The ballet, with the exception of Mlle Greppi, who danced charmingly, was a little disappointing, and the chorus still leaves something to be desired. The orchestra, under the direction of M. Baron, did excellent work. Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst were present on Tuesday evening,

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: (From "Al Garida.")

1. The Alexandria Municipal Commission never achieves any elaborate enterprise, because the non-experience of the members of the municipality and the ignorance of some of them of modern science prevent them from ably filling their seats and meeting the requirements of the city.

Moreover the Alexandrians do not take much interest in electing experts in trades and arts to represent them and enlighten the commission with their experience on questions connected with the vital undertakings that are discussed.

The merchants, notables and men of position either natives or foreign residents agree with each other to elect themselves and by doing so they leave no place for selecting candidates for public election.

The Alexandria Municipality, wishing to render some services to the city after the collapse of the houses, enacted the Building Regulations in order to improve what was ruined by the vicissitudes of time.
But the complaints raised against these regulations are enough to show their futility, for they give the municipal engineer excessive authority over those who wish to build houses.
Had the municipality been composed of experts in arts and crafts, gach regulations would not have been enacted.

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
APPOINTMENT OF ENGINEERS.
div.p: The misrepresentations in which our ultranationalist contemporary "Al Lewa," alias "Egyptian Standard," alias "Etendard Egyptien" indulges are well illustrated by the following concatenation of inaccuracies, which we extract from "L'Etendard Egyptien":

"oyeuse aventure : la Municipalité d'Alexandrie a nommé, à la suite d'un conconrs, plusienrs ingénieurs d'Angleterre ou d'ailleurs à des postes différents dans son administration. Tous les élus ont en soin de prendre le premier bateau et de rejoindre leurs postes. Excepté un. Celui-là se trouve à Marseille. Il a bien voulu se déranger pour aller de Lon. dres jusqu'à Marseille. Mais la Cannebière lui a donné des idées, et voici qu'il écrit à la municipalité : "Oa bien vous me payez mes frais de voyage, du bien je ne bouge pas." Entre temps, il collectionne les books chez Marius. La Municipalité hésite. Faut-il payer, faut-il ne pas payer ! Ce qui est vraiment embetunt, c'est que la plapart des oes "élus" ont été nommée parce qu'ils étaient présentés par des parrains influents et notoires. Va t-on mécontenter les parrains de celui-là i Tel est le casse-tête posé devant nos édiles. Il est certain, toutefois, qu'il serait regrettable de voir s'envoler pour quelques centames da franos de plus ou de moins, un savant et zélé serviteur de la ville. Si l'on se met à faire des économies, où allons-nous"

Such being the statements of our contemporary, it would perhaps be as well if we published the truth of the matter, which, doubtless our contemporary for political reasons prefers to voil. The facts are as follows:-A certain Genkin, of Russian (not English as averred by our worthy contemporary)nationality was appointed to one of the vacant posts. He gave the Municipality much trouble by his demands for guarantees, a contract, payment of passage money etc., all of which were, in accordance with the custom, refused. Subsequently he refused to take up the appointment and we are not at all surprised that his refusal was accepted.

As to the various appointments that have been made, we can conscientiously assert that no fairer method of appointment could have been adopted. The appointments were under the selection of a committee of three councillors, two of whom were engineers, and we are able to state that no recommendations from friends were put before the committee, while the selections of the committee were afterwards considered by the delegation. Seven permanent engineers in all were appointed and of these not one was an Englishman. There were, however, five English engineers appointed, on & five years' contract for the drainage work only in Alexandria, and it is as well to note that out of 450 applications 300 were made by Englishmen.
and of the
a five year English englishman

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Charles of Bourbon and his bride, the sister of the Due d'Orleans, who were married recently at Wood Norton, are coming to Egypt for their honeymoon.

The suggestion that Sir Henry CampbellBannerman should visit Egypt in order to improve his health after his recent breakdown is not to be carried out, as the doctors have deemed it inadvisable that he should undertake the long railway journey overland.
Vicomte E. Melchoir de Voguë, the French Academician, is arriving in Egypt in January, and will proceed to Upper Egypt in company with M. Charmes, of the Suez Canal Company.
Sir William Garstin will accompany Sir Eldon Gorst to Sudan next month when he is to meet Mr. Winston Churchill at Khartoum.
Mr. Emanuel Benachi, President of the Hellenic community of Alexandria, is arriving from Greece this afternoon by the Russian steamer.
Mr. Ayerst Henham Hooker has been apI pointed Norwegian Consul in Cairo.
Hassan Bey Mazloum, private secretary to the Financial Adviser, has been appointed in place of Socrates Bpiro Bey, director of the Central Administration of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration.
Mr. and Mrs Lang Anderson will go to Cairo this afternoon for a few days visit to the Savoy Hotel
A very old Cairo resident, M. Louis Sault, of the confectionery in the Sharia Marakh died yesterday.

The salary of Abdul Khalik Bey Sharwat, the newly appointed Modir of Assiout Province, has been raised to L.E. 1,200 per year, Hassan Bey Haseeb, Mudir of Minieh will receive L.E. 900 per annum and Ahmed Bey Kamal L.E. 720 per annum.

div.head: THE 1908 BUDGET.
div.p: As briefly reported in our issue of yesterday the Finance Committee has submitted to the Council of Ministers the proposed Budget for 1908, the main points of which are as follows:

The total receipts are estimated at L.E. 15,080,000, and the expenditure at L.E. 14,780,000 divided under the headings 1) Ordinary expenses LE.18,760,000, (2) Special expenses for 1908 LE 600,000, (8) Credits for the special expenses carried over from 1907 to 1908 LE. 870,000. The receipts are thus estimated to exceed the expenditure by L.E. 300,000.
RECEIPTS. The estimate of receipts for 1908 exceeds those of 1907 by L.E. 290,000, the increases being distributed as follows:

Land taxes and dues on urban property LE 25,000; Customs and tobacco L.E. 110,000; Harbour dnes LE. 10,000; Railways and Telegraphs LE. 330,000; Post L.E. 20,000 : Various receipts LE. 69,000; Rentals L.E. 15,000; Retained from salaries L.E. 12,000 ; Sudan Government L:E. 45,000; thus making a total of LE. 627.000.

Against these increases a decrease of LE. 62,000 is anticipated in certain sources of revenue such as registration charges, Mekhemeh receipts, interest on sume placed out, and two branches of revenue, to wit the sums paid for exemption from military service and the sale of Government property which were entered on last year's budget at L.E. 275,000. Thus the net estimated increase in receipts is reduced to the figure given above, L.E. 29,000.

The Railway receipts include a sum of L.E. 25,000 as the probable revenue from the auxiliary line of Upper Egypt, which was acquired in 1966 but the receipts and expenses of which have not up to now been included in the Budget.

The revenue from release from military service will from the 1st of January 1908 figure in & special account to be devoted to the amelioration of the condition of conscripts in the army and the police.
The revenue from the sales of Government land will henceforth be contributed to the general reserve.
EXPENDITURE The estimated expenditure of 1908, as already stated, is LE. 14,780,009, being an increase of I. E. 449,000 over 1907. The increases in the most important credits are as follows:--

MINISTRY OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION.-Increase of L E. 76,450 for the development of all branches of edncation, the creation of the school of Cadis, the organisation of the Agricultural Administration and of Industrial Education, and the amelioration of the condition of the fikis and arifs.

MINISTRY OF THE INTERIOR.-(Central Administration and Police). Increase of L.E. 14,045 for postal expenses and equipment of offices, formally under special chapters but now to be included in the Budgets of the Administrations, for the amelioration of the situation of mains and police officers and ser. geants, and for the increase in credits for various expenses owing to the areas of clothing and living
SANITARY SERVICES ---Increase of L.E.12,865, chiefly necessitated by the cost of living and of provisions, by the postal expenses, and by the extension of the street cleaning service.

Prisons. Increase of L.E. 46,210, L.E. 38,000 of which is due to the addition to the general Budget of receipts and expenses attached to the industrial works of the prisoners which up to the present have been noted in a special account, and, as regards the balance, on account of the increased cost of living and clothing.

MINISTRY OF JUSTICE. Increase of L.E 43,529 for the amelioration of the situation of the cadis, the creation of posts in the Mixed Tribunals, and the increase in credits for various expenses, chiefly legal fees and salaries of copyists.

MINISTRY OF PUBLIC WORKS.-Increase of LE. 53,583 in consequence of the application of the new programme for the engagement of Egyptian candidates in the higher executive posts, the development of the irrigation service and the towns and buildings service, the creation of local commissions, and increased subventions to certain existing permissions.

VARIOUS SERVICES OF THE MINISTRIES. ---Net diminution of L.E. 18,746 resulting, on the one hand, from the distribution of the credit estimated in the Budget of these services for the equipment of offices among the State administrations and the reduction of credit caused by the equalization of taxes, and, on the other hand, the increase in subvention to the Khedivjal Horticultural Society and the increase in credit for córn for the poor of Mecca and Medina on account of the increased cost of these.. .

PROVINCES AND GOVERNORS. - Increase of LE. 37,989 occasioned by the postal expenses, the equipment of offices formerly charged to other accounts, the increase in contributions by the Government for ghaffirs to guard the railway lines, and the automatic increase in the last "Cadre" class.
COAST GUARD.-Increase of LB. 13.335 for the creation of a dromedary corps at Mersa Matrouh and Sidi Barrani and the increase of various expenses, chiefly postal and equipment of offices.

RAILWAYS AND TELEGRAPHS.-Increase of LE. 264,095 due to the increase of receipts corresponding to a supplement of expenses, to the dearness of coal, the addition of the expenses of parcels delivery which were up to the present deducted directly from the receipts and to the addition to the Budget of an estimate for auxiliary lines of Upper Egypt
Post.-Increase of LE 20,800 for extension of service.
provisions, and, to a less degree, to the increase of the Arab force and various ameliorations with the object of increasing the mobility of the army.

CHANGES IN STEP.-Although the credit of L E. 72,000 written down to this title in 1907 has been maintained in form in the Budget of 1908, the question of staff will be settled shortly and this credit will be distributed among the State Administration to the situation of the classed staff.
SUPPRESSION OF Free POSTAGE. The credit. of L.E. 36,000 entered on the Budget of 1907 under this heading has been divided among the State administrations in the 1908 Badget.

Special EXPENSES IN 1908. The totality of these expenses is fixed at LE. 600,000, which is a diminution of L.L. 168,000 in comparison with 1907. The sum includes an increased credit for the building of schools.

CREDITS CARRIED Over. The special credits remaining unemployed at the end of 1907 to be carried over to 1908 are estimated at L.E. 370,000, an increase of L E. 50,000 over those carried over from 1906 to 1907.
SPECIAL EXPENSES. The special expenses for the year 1908 are given as follows:

MINISTRY OF FINANCE. Verification of Sha. rakis L.E. 3,500 ; Cadastral Survey L.E.37,950 ; Topographical Survey L.E. 14,600; Geological Survey L.E 5,000; Precision and Observatory L E. 7,850; Special scientific works L.E. 8 . Chemical and physical laboratory LE. 1,600; Inventory of State property L.E. 5,000; Inventory of plans of State property L.E. 200. Total L.E. 78,700.

MINISTRY OF THE INTERIOR. Behera mondi rieb LE. 18,000 ; Deshna markaz L.E. 6,575; Police post at Port Rosette L.E. 1,350 ; Police School at Abbassieh LE. 26,000; Installation of Police School in its new quarter at Abbassieh LE 500; Hydrants at Cairo L.E. 1,000 at Ghezireh LB. 50; at Koubbeh, Leitoun and Måtarieh LE. 500 Total L.B. 58,425.

SANITARY SERVICES. Lanatie Asylum at Kbanka L.E. 15,000, at Abbassieh L.E. 10,000; Alterations at Alexandria hospital LE. 6,500 ; Lodging at Merss Matrouh hospital L.E. 500; Filings up of birkets L.E. 2,500; Removal of Cemeteries L.E. 2,000, Total L.E. 86,000.
Prisons. Reformatory L.E. 16,500 ; Secondary prison at Damanhour LE. 7,000; Works in different prisons L.E. 5,000. Total LE 28,500.

SUPPRESSION OP SLAVERY. Establishment of a new post at Moent Verna L.E. 1,750; Construction of a house for inspectors at Erkowit L.E. 500.; Repairs of inspectors' house, barracks, stables, etc., at Khartoum L.E. 676; Complement of the price of a steam boat. L.B. 1,050 ; Purchase of arms and ammunition L E. 900. Total L.E. 4,176.
REFORM TRIBUNALS. Renewal of furniture I.E..800.
NATIVE TRIBUNALS. Construction of a Summary Tribunal at Shibinel Kom L.E. 1,000 ; Renewal of furniture L.E.200. Total L.E.1,200.
MEKHEMRHS. Reorganisation of archives LE, 1,000.

MINISTRY OF PUBLIC WORKS. (a) Irrigation (Egypt). Strengthening of eanal banks in newly converted basins L.B. 7,000 : Re making of canals in Lower Egypt I.E. 60,000. (b) Buildings. Tanzim office at Minieh L.E. 2,803 ; Works of aménagement L.E. 7,800. (C) Town. of Cairo. Bonlee bridge L.E. 40,000 ; Enlargement of Abou Ela bridge L.B 5,600; Construction of Kasr el Ali quay L E. 9,000 ; Conan tion of streets in the Garden City LB.6,500 Construction of a road from Rodah bridge to Ghizeh village and expropriation of lands LE. 4.500. Total L.E. 142,603,
VARIOUS SERVICES. Study of Sleeping Sickness L.E. 1,000; Registration of Bedouins L.E. 9,899. Total L E. 10,899.
ADMINISTRATIVE AND Tax-COLLECTING SERVICES OF THE PROVINCES AND GOUVERNORATS. Renewal of turniture L.E. 1,211.
CUSTOMS, Purchase of hydraulic press L.E. 500.

Coast-GUARDS, (a) Marine. Repairs to eroisers LE. 1,000 ; Schooner for the Gulf of Suez LE 250 : Repairs to the condenser and to the boats at Kosseir L.E. 104; Purchase of a rowing boat. for instructing recruits LE. 90. (b) Stores. Automatic turning machine and hammer LE. 267 Spare screws for the launches L.E. 80, (e) North direction Installations and various works at Ras-el-Tin L.B. 207; Movable target with guns and ammunition LE. 54. (d) East Direștion, New basin at the workshop island LE 900 ; New forge L.E. 20; Completing the Port Tewfik barracks L.E. 550; Reservoir and pump for furnishing water to the latrines of the Port Tewfik barracks LE. 200; Instruments and hand crane for workshops LE. 295. (e) Desert direction. Boring a well and installing a pump at Sidi Barrani LE 600 ; Repairing buildings at Campamento L E 400. Total L.E. 5,077.

TELEGRAPHS. Purchase of a launch L.B. 800; Telegraph lines from Cairo to Wasta L.B 759 ; from Kom Ombo to Asonan LE 180 from Sobag to Guirguis L. E. 105; from. Maghagha to Beni-Mazar L.E. 55; from Daft Samra to Baltim 540 ; New line to Halfa LE. 550. Total LE. 2,950.
Posts. Post offices at Tantah L.B. 13,440, at Port Tewfik LE 17,500 : at Damanhour LE. 500; at Kafr el Zayat LB. 6,500; Works and various purchases L.E. 700. Total LE. 38,360.

MINISTRY OF WAR Completion of barracks at Abbassieh L2. 50,500; at Ras el Tin L.E. 450 ; Various Buildings in the Sudan L.B. 20,000.; Initial Expenses of the Arab battalion L.E. 2,000; Manuals etc. L.E. 610; Purchase of hospital or LB 100. Total L.E. 73,660.

ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY. Contribution of the Government toward the construction of bridges on the Mahniondieh Canal L E.8,164. - QUARANTINE Counct Building of quarantine offices at the aisenal LE 12,000; New houses for pilgrims at Tor I. E. 10,000; Drainage works at Tor Camp LE. 6,800.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: Toujons à cause du raffermissement des valeurs égyptiennes à Londres, nous avons eu ce matin, une consolidation de l'amélioration d'hier avec une nonvelle avance. Il y a en sur l'ensemble de la cote 'un courant d'affaires assez facile et suivi, auquel nous n'étions plus habitués depuis longtemps. Pourvu qu'on continue à nous cabler de bonnes nouvelles, tout ira bien? A signaler en particulier une bonne demande en Tramways d'Alexandrie à 141, en Preference Béhéra à 4 1/8 et en Sidi Salem 4,2 1/8.

Parmi nos titres dirigeants, l'Agricole progrogge de 7 3/4 à 7 13/16, la National Bank de 20 1/8 à 20 5/16 et la Delta Light de 9 3 4 à 9-13/16, tandis que l'Obligation Crédit Foncior fléobit de 286 à 285 1/2 l'ancienne et de 254 à 253 la nouvelle.
En hausse les Privilégiées Tramways de 140 À 141, l'Alexandria Water de 10 & 10 1/8, les actions de capital Eaux du Caire de 105 A 108 et l'Urbaine de 2 15/16 à 3.
Continuent, au contraire, à fléchir les Privi. légiées Bière d'Alexandrie de 125 à 120, et le Crédit Franco Egyptien de 4 1/16 à 4.

Dans la catégorie des valeurs secondaires, la Salt & Soda reprend de 14 # 14/3 ; la Delta Land avance de 1 7/32 à 1 9/32, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 21/- à 21/6, l'Investment de 11/32 3/8, le Comptoir de 2 1/2 à 2 9/16, et l'Aboukir de 25/6 à 28/9. Seule dans ce nombre la Cassa di Sconto recule de 43 à 42 1/2.
Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de changements à signaler, faute d'affaires.

Les enchères, aujourd'hui seulement sug. pendues, reprendront lundi prochain, 2 dé. cembre. Il sera vendu pour compte de Serpos Bey 50 Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie, 61 actions Frigorifiques d'Egypte, 96 actions de capital et 45 actions de Jouissance Eaux du Caire

Au point de vue de la tendance il n'y a pag autre chose à dire sinon qu'elle dépend totale. ment de l'orientation du Stock Exchange, qui pour l'instant est excellente en ce qui concerne Ter valeurs égyptiennes.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries and Boutigny Ltda
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Jeudi 28 Novembre 1907.
Le taux de l'escoinpte libre à Londres est renseigné en baisse de 3/8 à 6 1/8 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, les Consolides anglais ont haassé hier de 1/4 à 82 1/2. L'Unifiée est restée inchangée à 99. La National Bank & avancé de 1/2 à 20 1/4 et l'Agricole de 1/4 å 7 7/8. La Daïra a bénéficié de 1/8 à 12 1/2. La Delta Light a été soutenue à 9 7/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien n gagné 2 francs à 683. La Banque d'Athènes 2 francs à 111 et les Lots Tures 2 francs à 166.
Delta Paris, do 9 La Banca 2 fram

loi, les nouvelles d'Europe nous ayant précisé le raffermissement du marché monétaire anglais, notre Bourse a suivi le mouvement avec une vivacité qui fait bien augurer de l'avenir. Les tendances de reprise qui s'étaient manifestées sur quelques titres un peu timidement hier se sont affirmées plus nettement ce matin et se sont étendues à tous les compartiments Les vendeurs d'antan doivent amèrement regretter d'avoir trop facilement prêté l'oreille à des racontars de baissiers en mal de rachats. En plus, signe des temps, le volume des transactions a considérablement augmenté et, pour le début d'une reprise, les plus difficiles étaient satisfaits.

Vors la clôture, il s'est produit comme il est naturel, une légère réaction sur les valeurs qui s'étaient le plus vivement relevées. Cela tient évidemment aux ventes forcées dont nous par lions ces derniers jours et qui pour s'arrêter par instants n'en restent pas moins menaçantes. Il est à présumer cependant que les capitalistes avertis profiteront de chaque réaction, qui pourrait se produire a l'avenir, pour améliorer le prix de revient de leurs dossiers. Il ne faut pas oublier que la confiance renaissant, les positions qui restent à liquider n'étant plus très nombreuses seront facilement absorbées.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National Bank s'inscrit invariée « 20 1/8 après avoir fait 20 1/4. L'Agricole est à 7 3/4-13/16 comme bier. La Banque d'Athènes se consolide à 109 alors que la Banque d'Orient réaetionne à 113. La Cassa di Sconto est en petite reprise à 42-43. Les H. de Vries and Bontigny Ltd. haussent à 0 7/16.

La Delta Light reprend à 9 13/16.La Ramleb Railways se releve encore & 4 S.S. La Daira Sanieh gagne 3/16 a 12 1 2. Le Crédit Foncier Egyptien avance à 680 et son obligation ancienne à 285-286. La privilégiée Béhéra réagit à 4 1/16-1/8. La Compagnie Immobilière se tasse å 288 et sa part à 380 en perte de 15 francs. L'Enterprise and Development est en gain de 1/4 7, ce que perd sa part, à 9 1/4. L’Agricole da Nil s'affaisse à 160. Les Entre priseImmobilières et Travaux sont l'objet d'un mouvement de reprise qui les porte à 1 3/16-1/4 ; les fondateurs participent à cette activité à P.T. 21-22. La Brasserie d'Alexan drie tombe à 120. L'Anglo-American Nile re. eule à 2-2 1/16 et les Omnibus-Automobiles à 2.

Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Baebler ac. centuent leur reprise à 4 11/16 tandis que les National Hotels réactionnent á 2 5/16 et les Upper Egypt à 2 1/2-9/16. Les Ritz 89 ressai. sissent à 05/16-8/B.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land très en faveur remonte à 1 1/4, l'United Land Å 0 1/4 et l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail à 20/9.
Nous détachons de notre correspondance de • Londres en date du 22 courant les passages
suivants :

"La semaine en revue a conservé, une attitude expectante, changeant d'allure suivant les nouvellos d'Amérique, tour à tour opti. mistes ou pessimistes. En général, la lourdeur et l'inactivité ont prédominé. Cela n'a du reste rien d'étonnant et l'on s'y résignait facilement vu le taux élevé du loyer de l'argent, qui gene sérieusement les affaires.
"Néanmoius, dans les millieux financiers de la Cité on espère une amélioration prochaine, la surexcitation des américains commençant à se calmer.
"Nos Consolidés et tous les autres Fonds d'Etat ont eu un marché très irrégulier et ont été plutot négligés. Il y a eu pourtant un peu plus d'activity en Chemins Américains et Canadiens.

"Le compartiment des valeurs égyptiennes a été très déprécié cette semaine, de conti: nuelles offres arrivant d'Egypte alors que le marché très restreint pouvait difficilement les absorber. Elles ont néanmoins conservé quelques acheteurs convaincus et pour peu que les. conditions monétaires redeviennent meilleures, nous les verrons reprendre très rapidement une ascension progressive. Les petites valeurs de ce groupe ont de la peine à changer de mains, les acheteurs offrant des prix fort en dessous de ceux exigés par les vendeurs.

"On se base pour pronostiquer une détente monétaire sur l'esprit pratique des américains qui préféreront certainement employer leur or improductif en prenant les bons du Trésor 3% offerts par le gouvernement. Cela permettra à ce dernier de venir en aide aux banques, et des locs on peut espérer que les drainages d'or cesseront en Europe.
Notre correspondant de Londres nous informe que le Conseil d'Administration des "Egyptian Estates" annonce qu'il ne sera pas déclaré de dividende cette année sur les actions ordinaires de la Société.
Du ler au 23 Novembre les importations d'or en Egypte ont été de LE. 871,606 et les exportations de L.E. 16,565, non compris le mouvement d'espèces qui alien par la Poste.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways.
div.p: NOTICE.
Trains de Laxe composed of sleeping and dining-cars, will run between Cairo and Luxor as follows --
From Cairo, every Monday, Wednesday, and Saturday, at 6.30 p.m., on and after 2nd December
From Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday, and Sunday, at 6.30 pm. on and after 3rd December.
A second class carriage will be attached to these trains for passengers' servants only.
The sleeping and dining-cars on the night Expresses leaving Cairo at 8 pm., and Luxor at 5.30 p.m., will be suppressed from the above dates.
Passengers are requested to book their births early through the Sleeping Car Company, Cairo Station.
Cairo, 27th November, 1907. 31412-2-1

div.head: NICOLAS ADAMIDIS DECEASED
div.p: PURSUANT TO THE Act 22 & 23 VICTORIA.

CHAPTER 35. NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that all Creditors and other persons having any claims or demands upon or against the estate of Nicolas Adamidis late of Alexandria, Egypt (who died on the 9th day of July 1906 and Letters of Administration of whose estate in Egypt were in pursuance of an order of His Britannie Majesty's Consular Court at Alex andria (Probate Jurisdiction) dated the 28th day of March 1907, granted to James Hewat of Alexandria out of His Britannie Majesty's Consular Court (Probate Jurisdiction) on the 30th day of April 1907) are hereby required to send particulars, in writing, of their claims or demands to us, the undersigned, Advocates to the said James Hewat, on or before the 31st day of December 1907, and that at the expiration of that time, the said James Hewat will distribute the assets of the said deceased among the parties entitled thereto having regård only to claims and demands of which he shall have had notice. Dated this 29th day of November 1907.
LEVRAUX & HALPORD. 6 Old Bourse Street, Alexandria. Advocates to the above-named Administrator.

div.head: ITALIAN CHAMBER OF DEPUTIES. ALEXANDRIA'S ITALIAN COLONY.

div.p: Chamber of Deputies. Signor Tittoni reply: ing to Deputies Signori Vicini, Monteguarneri, and Santini said that the Freemasons had arbitrarily placed an inscription offensive to the religion in the Italian School in Alexandria. Only 800 out of 80,000 Italians had attended the Freer ason's meeting to protest against the Consul's removal of the inscription. The Government, he said, would shortly place in the School an unsectarian inscription composed by Senator Villari.
Signor Vicini said that the Government's interference with a school built by the Colony was unjustified.
Signori Monteguarneri and Bantini were satisfied with the reply.
Bignor Nasi bas demanded the right of exercising the functions of a deputy of which the Senate had unlawfully deprived him.
(Reuter)

div.head: AMERICAN CRISIS. SUBSCRIPTIONS TO TREASURY CERTIFICATES CLOSED.

div.p: Mr. Cortelyou announces that the list of subscriptions to the Treasury Certificates has been closed. In view of the decided improvement in business it is probable that no further allotments will be made. The amount of the subscriptions has not been stated. (Reuter)
The Mayor of Nemours has potified the General commanding the district that a strong Moorish column is advancing towards Nemours. Troops have been dispatched. (Reuter)
The Governor of Algeria telegraphs that ,000 Moorish tribesmen raided the Algerian frontier on Tuesday destroying some gardens. They then retired. .(Reuter) •
General Picquart announced to the Chamber of Deputies that the Algerian frontier incident will be settled with the Maghzen. The bands will receive exemplary punishment. (Havas)
The Bab el Asab fight lasted two hours. We had twelve killed, including Lt. de Saint HiJaire. The reinforcements have repulsed the Beni Snassens from the frontier. (Havas)

Moorish raiders on Tuesday attacked the French post of Bab el-Assah. After 6 hours fighting they were repulsed by the garrison consisting of 100 men. The post lost 10 men killed and 6 wounded and was relieved by detachments sent from Nemours and Ujda.
(Reuter)
100 Bulgarians have attacked the Servian village of Otaobnitza (Macedonia). Turkish troops pursued them, killing 50 of them, including the chief Sterieolachtche. (Reuter)
Mr. John Redmond, speaking at Merthyr Tydvil, said that next season would see the Irish party absolutely united. (Reuter)
Speaking at the Reichstag Prince von Buelow retaliated to the attacks of Mr. Harden.
(Havas)

div.head: THE ARTIFICIAL STONE COMPANY.
div.p: * want much felt in Alexandria as well as Tin most other places in lower Egypt is that of a good building material;- it is true that in Alexandria we have some fine blocks of buildings which do credit to their architects and builders, and for a time they have a smart appearance, but in a few years the
plaster begins to peel off from the soft stone | of which they are built, and then large expense

is required if appearances are to be kept up. | Again in case of fire the soft Maxstone is a dangerous material as was amply shown in the enormous fire which followed the bombardment of Alexandria in 1882. Huge blocks of buildings crumbled down like a house of cards before the fire had gone higher than the first floor, because the store began to turn into lime, and could no longer support the superstructure. Not only has the Mex stone,—the principal building material used in Alexandria--these and many other defects, but the quarries are becoming exhausted and every day it is getting scarcer and dearer. On the other hand there has within recent 1 years, even in countries like America, England, and Switzerland where good natural stone is abundant, been an enormous development of the use of artificial stone, of which the principal ingredients are Portland cement and sand, of which blocks can be moulded to suit every shape required, either for the builder's art or for paving, kerb stones, drain pipes,

The Artificial Stone Company has been formed to supply this material in all its various | forms. It has works both in Cairo and Alexandria, At the former, a considerable amount of work has already been done, but the works at Alexandria, on the canal bank at Moharram Bey, have only lately been started. We visited them recently and found several thousand blocks of stone of all shapes and sizes, some quite freshly made and others already hard and fit for use. All of them have a very pleasing and substantial appearance and walls built with them will not require any external plastering / we were told that samples have been submitted to severe tests and have shown this stone to be more capable of bearing weight, than any of the building material generally used in this country. The stones are moulded in special machines, which give great facilities for turning them out, of very accurate shape and size. - The Company is about to start making paving stones suitable for footpaths. These have been used with great advantage in many towns in Europe and America, and have many advantages. They are cheaper and harder than most of the natural stones, and now that it is the fashion to lay electric telephone and light wires in the footpaths, which require tronches to be frequently opened in them, this paving has great facilities of being taken up and relaid without showing the hideous marks which disfigure the expensive asphalt pavements all over the town. In the town of Folkestone, one of the cleanest and best kept towns in Europe, all the footpaths are laid with this sort of artificial stone, and it has given the greatest satisfaction.

Many of the companies recently formed in Egypt have hardly been able to justify their existence, but we feel sure that this company will help to supply a material which is much required for the development of this country. The directors of the company are men who have both the technical and financial knowledge required for the successful carrying out of such an undertaking and its managing director has had more experience of this class of work than probably any other man in this country

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS.
div.p: ANOTHER NEW PARTY.

That section of the Moderate Nationaliste, which follows the opinions of "Al Mosyad," has begun to make a serious attempt to organise itself as an active political entity. The Sheikh Aly Youssef has taken up question most energetically and he has of lato presided over

number of committee meetings at which the programme of the party was discussed and its statutes passed. We understand that a document embodying the result of these deliberations is on the eve of publication. It is too soon a prophecy as to the prospects of this organisation and it is foolish to pour cold water on the enterprise, as some of our contemporaries have already done, for nobody knows what its programme is to be. "The more the merrier,''so far as Egyptian political parties are concerned, is the wisest attitude to adopt and we consequently welcome the arrival of the Yousspfite section of the Moderate Nationalist party and hope that it will emerge from its incubatory stage as an energetio organism.

The cankering evil in the public life of Egypt is the rooted disbelief in anyone's-- least of all a journalişt's-sincerity; and as each of the soi-disant "Parties'' has been engineered by Journalists they are all suffering from the same inherent weakness. In our opinion the popularity of the party of Sheik Ali Bey Yussef will depend not so much upon its principles, which, it may be presumed, have, in great measure, been foreshadowed in the speeches and interviews of the Sheik, as upon the energy and resolution with which their propaganda is carried on.

Úp till now, with the exception of a single speech from Kamel at Alexandria the other "Parties'' have confined their proselytizing efforts to the issuing of manifestoes in the Press and the sending of telegrams, Those are not very surprising or efficacions methods of making converte. Political warfare to be real and effective requires a great deal more than this arm-chair species of pastime. The propagandist who would attract to his side enthusiastic adherents in any appreciable number must leave his writing desk and step down into the arena. Signs are manifesting themselves that the leaders of the newly organized party, which, we hear, is to concern itself largely with constitutional reform, will be the first to enter the lists by undertaking a regular campaign.
THE PARTY QUESTION.

The Cairo Coptio organ "Al Watan", remarks :-They are certainly right, these gentlemen of the local European Pregs who make our political parties the subject of their sneers and merry jokes. They have found out at last that our contention Bo often reiterated in these columns have the only interpretation of party politics in Egypt. To our mind the patriotism of our Mohammedan compatriots, or at least of those who were parading their patriotic and nationalist pretentions among them, was no more than the pursuit of gain. Our patriots were only serving their own personal ends by championing this or that cause, the principle of public service being the farthest thing in the world from their thoughts. Mustafa Kamel calls himself an extreme Nationalist because he finds no better meads for living nowadays. Ali Youssef and his creatures of "Al Minbar" are Moderates now because a shew of moderation is the best policy for their pockets. The founders of "Al-Garida" or the wire pullers among them, call themselves a moderate political party because they can win privileges and posts by the adopted hypocrisy of these days. There are no parties here; there are only persons serving their own interests under various guises. We may hear of a new attempt at party making every week now that the so-called leaders are rivalling in their attempts to gain the favour and the money of those who phone to believe in them or hope to reach certain goals at their hands. If every news: paper editor is to follow the example of the Pasha and the Sheik we shall soon have as many mushroom parties as we care to count.

Amidst this astounding mass of falsehood and hypocrisy one section of our party-makers deserves a better description and more esteem. It is that party of young men mostly of the better class who form the Egyptian Liberal party and speak the mind of every sane and unbiased Egyptian having the courage of his opinions ; those who accept the present Government of Egypt as the best which the country has seen from the beginning of history. There's no doubt the genuine view of all with the Exception of those who think it their dutyrom a religious point of view to denounce the alien race now ruling Egypt and chew their hatred in certain ways. The Copts are, of course, unbiased in this way; there is only one party among them and one political creed. They are friendly to the present Government Though in certain matters they have cause to complain.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Orders have been received at the Provisional Cavalry Depot, Ballincollig, to prepare another draft of 52 non-commissioned officers and men to join the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, Cairo. This draft will be dispatched in January.
Lieutenant Vickery, D.8.0. Royal Field Artillery, has been formally seconded for service with the Egyptian Army. He earned his decoration in the South African War.

Lieutenant Colonel Sir F.B.M. Henniker. Bart., King's Royal Rifle Corps, will embark at Southampton on the troopship Rewa the 18th proxo, for India en route to take up the command of the 2nd Battalion at Jubbulpore.
In a letter from an officer, received lately from Kharton and published in the "Army and Navy Gazette." it is said:
"You know, of course, that we have lost Major Persse of the Bays, who has been in

command of the cavalry for some time, and | has now returned to regimental daty. He is a great loss, for he had the forces under him thoroughly well in hand, and knew how to employ them to best advantage. He had, however, to decide between going back to the Bays or throwing in his lot with the Kbedivial forces altogether, as his limit of non-regimental duty had expired under the terms prescribed by Royal Warrant. The Bays are ordered home from South Africa, and when they arrive at their new station Persse will join them, presumably as second in command. They could not bave a better one, and his comfy and here should be to his advantage, for he has had no easy billet of it, I can assure you."

Yesterday, the troopship "Dongola '' left Southampton with the 1st Battalion Suffolk Regiment for Malta, together with a number of Indian drafts. The troopship will reach Valletta on the 27th inst, where she will put off the Suffolks and take on the 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers (for Chakrata) and proceed to Karachi. She is timed to reach Port Saia on the 30th inst,

All arrangements for the training of existing units of the auxiliary forces are to be held in abeyance pending the issue of instructions from the War Office on the subject. There are many obstacles yet to be overcome before the scheme is launched.

Most likely the last has been heard of the 5th Royal Irish Lancers sensational incident as Mr. Haldane has emphatically refused to re-open the question of placing the five officers on half pay. Perhaps, when the War Office blundered the whole matter so ingeniously that is the better course. The gallant Royal Irish Lancers have been acquitted of the slightest suspicion of inefficiency in the literal sense of the term, and it is not considered likely that even when the House opens its session that official countenance will be given to anyone desirous of re-opening the matter.
The battleship "Duncan" is to be re-fitted at Gibraltar before she returns home to England to pay off.
an official anbrity she will absurd pro

The new "Dreadnought" is to bear the time honoured name of the "Collingwood"-all speculation on the subject having been put at rest by an official announcement-but it is safe to say that to posterity she will be known as "The Hagne" if only to inark the absurd proceedings of the extremely absurd and arrogant, body whose desire to shear war of its borrowers could not include the prohibition of that most fiendish form of destruction-floating mines.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S DEBUT.
div.p: To The Horror OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE".

Sir Lord Cromer's debut as an active party politician must have excited and continues to provoke considerable discussion in political circles. For myself I confess it has thrown my mind into a condition of perplexity from which perhaps some of the readers of the "Egyptian Gazette kindly extricato it. For in the first place I cannot comprehend how & staunch and consistent advocate of Free Trade could have accepted in Egypt a general import duty of 8%. Perhaps it may have been thought inadvisable to alter Egypt's fiscal system and to raise revenue From OLDT sources. But that is & mere surmise based upon no tangible evidence whatsoever. My next difficulty arose øn reading the "Gazette's" special telegram published on the 23rd inst, on which Lord Cromer is represented as saying that our success in Egypt was mainly due to the principles of free trade having been rigidly applied. But what about the import duty" above alluded to 1 The greatest puzzle of all however was a telegram to "l'Egypte" of the 24th inst, which quotes the "Times” as alleging that Lord Cromer's radical and free trade declarations gravely compromise the Unionist alliance. My astonishment and mystification are two-fold I am at a loss to understand how the "Times" should fall foul of one whom it has in and out of season steadfastly supported and

I am still more amazed to learn that The | profession of free trade principles can in any way jeopardize the Unionist position. Why, if Lord Salisbury were now alive he too would I probably be a Free Trader.

Advertising again to the telegram to the "Gazette," it seems almost inconceivable that Lord Cromer could have affirmed that the Ascent of the Powers to the hybrid juridical situation in the Sudan was purchased at the price of no preference being given to the trade of any one nation, and that alike consideration secured general European acceptance of England's policy in Egypt. I can scarcely credit his Lordship with such cynicism and even if those were his views I find it next to impossible to believe that he would have given expression to them.
Faithfully Yours,
